question: A.001 [1.0 point] Why is the stable negative period following a scram always the same value, regardless of initial power level? The rate of power change is dependent on the:

question: A.004 [1.0 points] The fuel temperature coefficient of reactivity is -1.25E-4 delta k/k/deg.F. When a control rod with an average rod worth of 0.1% delta k/k/inch is withdrawn 10 inches, reactor power increases and becomes stable at a higher level. At this point, (ignoring any other temperature effects) the fuel temperature has:

answers.answer: a. increased by 80 deg.F.
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: Reactivity added by control rod = +(0.001 Δk/k/inch)((10 inches) = 0.01 delta k/k Fuel temperature change = - reactivity of rod/fuel temp. coeff. = (- 0.01 delta k/k)/(- 1.25E-4 delta k/k/deg. F) = 80 deg. F Glasstone, Section 5.96

answers.answer: b. decreased by 80 deg.F.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Reactivity added by control rod = +(0.001 Δk/k/inch)((10 inches) = 0.01 delta k/k Fuel temperature change = - reactivity of rod/fuel temp. coeff. = (- 0.01 delta k/k)/(- 1.25E-4 delta k/k/deg. F) = 80 deg. F Glasstone, Section 5.96

answers.answer: c. increased by 8 deg.F.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Reactivity added by control rod = +(0.001 Δk/k/inch)((10 inches) = 0.01 delta k/k Fuel temperature change = - reactivity of rod/fuel temp. coeff. = (- 0.01 delta k/k)/(- 1.25E-4 delta k/k/deg. F) = 80 deg. F Glasstone, Section 5.96

answers.answer: d. decreased by 8 deg.F.

question: A.005 [1.0 points] Suppose the temperature coefficient of a core is -2.5 E10-4 ΔK/K/°C and the average control rod worth of the regulating control rod is 5.895 E10-3 ΔK/K/inch. If the temperature INCREASES by 50°C what will the automatic control command the regulating rod to do? Select the answer that is closest to the calculated value.

question: A.014 [1.0 points] The delayed neutron precursor β for U235 is 0.0065. However, when calculating reactor parameters you use the effective delayed neutron precursor βeff with a value of ~0.0070. Which ONE of the following is the correct reason that βeff is larger than β?

answers.answer: a. Delayed neutrons are born at higher energies than prompt neutrons resulting in a greater worth for the neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect.

answers.answer: b. Delayed neutrons are born at lower energies than prompt neutrons resulting in less leakage during slowdown to thermal energies.
answers.feedback: Correct.

answers.answer: c. U238 in the core becomes Pu239 (by neutron absorption), which has a higher β for fission.
answers.feedback: Incorrect.

answers.answer: d. The fuel also contains U238 which has a relatively large β for fast fission.
answers.feedback: Incorrect.
